q: What is a determinant?
a:
A determinant is a scalar value calculated only from a square matrix.
It represents the volume scaling factor of the linear transformation described by the matrix and helps in solving systems of linear equations.

q: How is the determinant of a $2\times2$ matrix calculated?
a:
For $A = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}$, the determinant is the difference of the products of the diagonals:
$$ |A| = ad - bc $$

q: How is the determinant of a $3\times3$ matrix calculated?
a:
If $A = \begin{bmatrix} a_1 & b_1 & c_1 \\ a_2 & b_2 & c_2 \\ a_3 & b_3 & c_3 \end{bmatrix}$, then expansion along the first row is:
\[ |A| = a_1(b_2c_3 - b_3c_2) - b_1(a_2c_3 - a_3c_2) + c_1(a_2b_3 - a_3b_2) \]

q: What is the geometric interpretation of a determinant?
a: The absolute value of the determinant represents the area (for $2\times2$ matrices) or volume (for $3\times3$ matrices) of the figure formed by the column vectors of the matrix.

q: What is the effect on determinant when two rows (or columns) are interchanged?
a:
Interchanging two rows ($R_i \leftrightarrow R_j$) or columns ($C_i \leftrightarrow C_j$) changes its sign.
That is, $|A'| = -|A|$.

q: What happens to the determinant if two rows (or columns) are identical?
a: If any two rows or columns of a matrix are identical, then the determinant is zero.

q: What is the effect on the determinant when a row (or column) is multiplied by a scalar $k$?
a:
The determinant gets multiplied by $k$.
That is, $|A'| = k|A|$. (Note: $\text{det}(kA) = k^n|A|$).

q: What is the value of the determinant if the matrix has a row or column of zeros?
a: If any row or column of a matrix is entirely zero, the determinant is zero.

q: What is the determinant of an identity matrix?
a: The determinant of an identity matrix ($I_n$) is always 1: $|I_n| = 1$.

q: State the property: $|A^T| = ?$
a: $$ |A^T| = |A| $$The determinant of the transpose of a matrix is equal to the determinant of the matrix itself.

q: If $|A| \neq 0$, what can be said about the matrix $A$?
a: If $|A| \neq 0$, then the matrix $A$ is non-singular and invertible ($A^{-1}$ exists).

q: If $|A| = 0$, what can be said about the matrix $A$?
a: If $|A| = 0$, then the matrix $A$ is singular and not invertible ($A^{-1}$ does not exist).

q: What is the adjoint of a matrix?
a:
The adjoint (or adjugate) of a square matrix $A$ is the transpose of its cofactor matrix ($ ext{cof}(A)$).
Formula: $\text{adj}(A) = (\text{cof}(A))^T$

q: What is the inverse of a matrix using the adjoint?
a:
If $A$ is a non-singular matrix, its inverse is defined as the adjoint divided by the determinant:
\[ A^{-1} = \frac{\text{adj}(A)}{|A|} \]

q: How do you solve a system of equations using Cramer's Rule?
a:
For a system $AX = B$, if $|A| \neq 0$, the unique solution is:
\[ x = \frac{|A_1|}{|A|}, \quad y = \frac{|A_2|}{|A|}, \quad z = \frac{|A_3|}{|A|} \]
where $A_i$ is $A$ with the $i^{th}$ column replaced by the column matrix $B$.

q: What is a cofactor?
a:
The cofactor of an element $a_{ij}$ is given by:
$C_{ij} = (-1)^{i+j}M_{ij}$
where $M_{ij}$ is the minor of $a_{ij}$.

q: What is a minor?
a: The minor of an element $a_{ij}$ is the determinant of the submatrix formed by deleting the $i^{th}$ row and $j^{th}$ column.

q: What is the expansion of a determinant along a row?
a:
The determinant $|A|$ is the sum of the products of elements of any row with their corresponding cofactors.
Expansion along the $i^{th}$ row:
\[ |A| = a_{i1}C_{i1} + a_{i2}C_{i2} + \dots + a_{in}C_{in} \]

q: What is the expansion of a determinant along a column?
a:
The determinant $|A|$ is the sum of the products of elements of any column with their corresponding cofactors.
Expansion along the $j^{th}$ column:
\[ |A| = a_{1j}C_{1j} + a_{2j}C_{2j} + \dots + a_{nj}C_{nj} \]

q: What is the value of $|kA|$, where $k$ is a scalar and $A$ is an $n \times n$ matrix?
What is the determinant of a product of two matrices?
a: The determinant of the product is the product of the individual determinants: $$ |AB| = |A| \cdot |B| $$

q: If $|A| = 5$, what is $|3A|$ for a $3\times3$ matrix?
a:
Using the property $|kA| = k^n |A|$ with $n=3$ and $k=3$:
$ |3A| = 3^3 \cdot |A| = 27 \cdot 5 = 135 $

q: If $|A| = 7$ and $|B| = 2$, what is $|AB|$?
a:
Using the property $|AB| = |A| \cdot |B|$:
$ |AB| = 7 \times 2 = 14 $

q: State the identity: $\text{adj}(A) \cdot A = ?$
a:
The product of the adjoint and the matrix equals the determinant times the identity matrix:
$$ \text{adj}(A) \cdot A = |A| \cdot I $$

q: What is $A \cdot \text{adj}(A)$?
a:
The matrix commutes with its adjoint, so:
$$ A \cdot \text{adj}(A) = |A| \cdot I $$

q: What is $\text{adj}(A^T)$?
a:
The adjoint of the transpose is the transpose of the adjoint:
$$ \text{adj}(A^T) = (\text{adj}(A))^T $$

q: What is $\text{adj}(kA)$?
a:
If $A$ is an $n \times n$ matrix and $k$ is a scalar, then:
$$ \text{adj}(kA) = k^{n-1} \cdot \text{adj}(A) $$

q: What is $|\text{adj}(A)|$ for an $n \times n$ matrix?
a:
The determinant of the adjoint is the determinant of the matrix raised to the power of $(n-1)$:
$$ |\text{adj}(A)| = |A|^{n-1} $$

q: If $|A| = 0$, what is the result of the product $\text{adj}(A) \cdot A$?
a: If $|A| = 0$, then $\text{adj}(A) \cdot A = |A| \cdot I = 0 \cdot I = O$ (the Zero Matrix).
